document_title: Chronic enteritis: Causes, symptoms and treatment
subsection_content:
Environmental factors thought to have an impact on the development of the disease include smoking, use of anti-inflammatory NSAIDs, use of immunosuppressive drugs or hormone replacement.
Genetic factors are highly related to both ulcerative colitis and Crohn's disease when the incidence of the disease in family members or identical twins is very high, up to 35% of the risk of IBD in family members. and 30% risk in identical twins. The most common age for Crohn's disease is between 20 and 30 years old, and the second age group is usually after 60 years old.
Smoking increases the risk of Crohn's disease and increases complications of strictures, fistulas, and the need for surgery. A diet high in fiber and fruit reduces the risk of Crohn's disease, while eating a lot of animal fat or unsaturated fatty acids increases the risk of Crohn's disease. Vitamin D deficiency is common in Crohn's disease.(1)
Currently, the incidence of IBD is tending to increase in the Asian population, the overall incidence varies from 1 to 16/100,000 people. In Asia, 36% of cases were diagnosed after complications of intestinal stricture or perforation compared to only 5% in Australia.
